title: 7 reasons to let your kids fail, according to psychology
text:
Children should know that their parents will love and support them, but it's a disservice to never let them fail.

Never failing will instill a sense of helplessness in kids, and could set them on path towards anxiety and depression — or entitlement.

Instead, it lets children see failure as an opportunity, and set goals that they'll follow through on.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.

No parent wants to see their child in pain. Especially for those of us who are natural "fixers," the urge to intervene and help a child avoid failure can be a potent force to reckon it, and one that comes with plenty of rationalizations.

Case in point: you notice your child left a project behind at home, and you'll be driving by their school later that morning anyway. There's no reason not to drop it off for them, right? They spent hours working on it, and it'll take you all of five extra minutes to leave it for them at the front office. Plus, it's not like you did the project for them or anything, so really, this situation is totally safe from falling into "helicopter parent" territory. Right?

Wrong. Every child needs to know that they have an unlimited source of support in their parents, who will love and accept them no matter how badly they've failed. What they don't need is to conflate that unconditional support with a shield protecting them from experiencing failure. In the end, that only does them a disservice. Here are seven reasons why.
description: Children should feel loved and supported, but protecting them constantly from failure is a disservice to them.
